title: Oman - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: Military Forces of the United States (2017-)

Movement of forces: On 23 December 2020, the U.S. Fifth Fleet announced that the USS Georgia, an Ohio Class nuclear submarine, passed through the Strait of Hormuz, coded as Jazirat Abu Chir (Musandem, Oman), along with two additional warships. The deployment comes ahead of the one year anniversary of the U.S. military operation that killed Qassem Soleimani.

Security measures: On 22 December 2020, Omani authorities closed the countries borders, with an exception for cargo transportation, following the discovery of a new strain of coronavirus in the United Kingdom. On 28 December 2020, Omani authorities announced that they would reopen all international border crossing on 29 December. Travel was originally restricted due to the discovery of a new strain of coronavirus in the UK.
Arab News; GardaWorld; Al Arabiya; Gulf News (UAE)

Security measures: On 10 April 2020, the government of Oman placed the capital Muscat under complete lockdown in an effort to slow down the spread of the coronavirus. On 30 May, the government lifted the lockdown. A nationwide night-time curfew will be implemented between 11 and 25 October, for the hours between 22:00 and 05:00, and will restrict any non-essential movement during those hours. New restrictions come as the number of coronavirus cases increased.

Security measures: On 17 March 2020, amidst the spread of the coronavirus, Oman restricted entry to the country only to Omani nationals. Omani nationals are however not allowed to depart to other countries.
Times of Oman; Oman Daily Observer

Security measures: On 15 March 2020, amidst the spread of the coronavirus, Oman closed all schools, universities and other educational institutions for 30 days - subject to review and evaluation. On 18 March, also all places of worship, cinemas, gyms, sport clubs, barber shops and all shops in shopping malls apart from foodstuff and medical outlets were closed and banned public all gatherings.

Non-violent activity: On 10 January 2020, Sultan Qaboos bin Said Al Said of Oman, the ruler of Oman, died from cancer aged 79. On 11 January 2020, Oman announced Haitham bin Tariq Al Said as the new ruler of the country. He is a cousin of late Sultan Qaboos, and a career diplomat who served as the minister of national heritage and culture.
Military Forces of the United States (2017-)
Military Forces of Iran (1989-) Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps

Weapons seizure: On 25 November 2019, US Navy forces reportedly confiscated a 'significant cache' of suspected Iranian guided missile parts. Weapons seized include 21 ''Dehlavieh'' anti-tank guided missiles; components for the Quds-1 land attack cruise missile, for a C802 anti-ship cruise missile and for a third, unidentified cruise missile and two previously unknown surface-to-air missiles. Weapons were seized in the Arabian sea off the coast of Oman.
Military Forces of Iran (1989-) Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps

Weapons seizure: On 25 June 2019, the Australian HMAS Ballarat seized 697 bags ammonium nitrate fertilizer and 475 000 rounds small calibre believed to have been manufactured in Iran in the Gulf of Oman near the coast in Muscat.
On 1/1/2019, a crowd protested outside the Ministry of Manpower in Al Mazyunah, demanding the government to provide more jobs.
On 1/1/2019, a crowd protested in Muscat, demanding the government to provide more jobs. Two journalists were arrested while covering the protest in front of the Ministry of Manpower in Muscat.
On 1/1/2019, a crowd protested in Salalah, demanding the government to provide more jobs.
On 28/10/2018, demonstrating against the visit of Israel's Prime Minister to Oman, a group of people in Muscat burnt the Israeli flag.

Young unemployed Omanis took to the streets in the southern port city of Salalah, capital of Dhofar governorate, to denounce the lack of job opportunities for university graduates. Three days later, on November 25, the government announced the creation of 25,000 jobs in the coming six months. Protests also took place in the capital Muscat.

Hundreds of young unemployed Omanis took to the streets in front of the ministry of manpower in the capital Muscat to denounce the lack of job opportunities for university graduates. Anti-riot police was present but did not intervene. Three days later, on November 25, the government announced the creation of 25,000 jobs in the coming six months. Protests also took place in the southern port city of Salalah, capital of Dhofar governorate.

Arrests: Around 31 July 2016 (from 17 Jul and 6 Aug), several raids took place across Oman by forces from Ministry of Manpower and Royal Oman Police (ROP), which resulted in the arrest of more than 378 foreign workers for violating labour laws in Oman, including workers from different sectors. The information reported that most of them were deported from Oman.
Military Forces of the United States (2017-)
Military Forces of Iran (1989-) Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps

Weapons seizure: On 28 March 2016, the USS Sirocco seized 500 AK-pattern assault rifles, 21 DShK-pattern heavy machine guns and 200 RPG launchers believed to have been manufactured in Iran in the Persian Gulf or the Arabian sea. Event coded in the Arabian sea off the coast of Oman.
Military Forces of Iran (1989-) Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps

Weapons seizure: On 27 February 2016, the Australian HMAS Darwin seized 1989 AK-pattern assault rifles, 49 PKM light machine guns, 100 RPG launchers, 20 60-mm mortars tubes believed to have been manufactured in Iran off the coast of Oman
